questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the definition of safe and wholesome water?
questions.solution:
Water intended for human consumption must be safe and wholesome. It must be colorless.

Safe and wholesome water is defined as:

  • Free from pathogenic agents
  • Free from harmful chemicals
  • Pleasant to taste, free from colour and odour
  • Usable for domestic purposes

Water is said to be polluted when it does not fulfill the above criteria.

questions.text: In an urban PHC, an increasing number of skin diseases are being reported due to inadequate water supply in the region. What would be the adequate supply of water for them to meet their needs for all domestic purposes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of skin diseases is suggestive of water-washed diseases caused by improper hygiene related to an inadequate water supply. In urban areas, 150–200 litres per capita per day is the recommended allowance to meet the needs for all kinds of domestic purposes.
In rural areas, the set target of water supply to be achieved in India is around 50-55 litres per capita per day.

questions.text: What are the norms for the required litres of water per capita per day in rural areas?
questions.solution:
According to the National Rural Drinking Water Programme, the requirement of water in rural areas (areas with public water posts) is 55 litres per capita per day. This is in accordance with the 12th Five Year Plan.

For reasons of comparability, the source of water provision in rural areas should be within a distance of 100 metres from the household or the time taken to fetch water should not be > 30 minutes.

Note: Park textbook mentions 40-50 litres per capita per day as the norm. However, in the 12th five year plan period, the Government of India enhanced the rural drinking water supply norms from 40 litres to 55 litres per capita per day.

questions.text: What is the purest form of water in nature?
questions.solution:
Rain water is the purest form of water in nature. It contains a very low amount of total dissolved solids (TDS). Rain water is the origin of both surface and ground water.

Sources of water:

  • Rain
  • Surface water:
    • Impounding reservoirs
    • Rivers and streams
    • Tanks, ponds and lakes
  • Ground water: 
    • Shallow wells
    • Deep wells
    • Springs

questions.text: Which of the following is not a source of surface water?
questions.solution:
Shallow wells are sources of ground water.

Sources of water:

  • Rain

    • Rivers and streams
    • Tanks, ponds and lakes
  • Ground water: 
    • Shallow wells
    • Deep wells
    • Springs

questions.text: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
questions.solution:
The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas.

Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-like water bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into which natural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs.

Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free from impurities. Catchment areas are the main sources of impurities in the water in impounding reservoirs.

questions.text: What is the most common type of well in India?
questions.solution:
Dug wells are the most common type of wells in India.

Related Pearl: Wells

  • Wells are a source of ground water and are widely used across India.
  • The two main types of wells are the shallow and deep wells, the difference between which are:
  Shallow Wells Deep Wells
Description They tap subsoil water, i.e., water from above the first impervious layer in the ground They tap water from the water-bearing stratum which is below the first impervious layer of the ground
Chemical quality Moderately hard water Very hard water
Contamination Very often grossly contaminated and liable to pollution Low contamination levels and purer than water from shallow wells
Yield Generally dry in summer Provides constant water supply
Prevalence in India Very common Less common than shallow wells
  • An artesian well is a type of deep well in which the water rises to the surface due to the pressure with which it is held between two impervious/impermeable layers. There is no pump or other manual methods needed to bring the water to the surface. These are not common in India.
  • Wells can also be classified according to the method of construction as dug wells and tube wells.

i) Dug wells:

  • They are the most common type of wells in India.
  • In rural India, two types of dug wells exist, namely the unlined katcha wells and the masonry or pucca wells.
  • The katcha wells are just big holes dug into the sand.
  • The pucca wells are well built with walls or linings made of brick or stones.
  • Step wells are types of pucca dug wells that have steps. These steps can be used by people to descend into the well and come in contact with water. This increases the risk of water contamination.

ii) Tube wells:

  • Shallow tube wells are also called driven wells and deep tube wells are called bore wells.
  • They are safer sources of water compared to other wells, relatively cheaper to build and maintain.
  • Tube wells use strainers at the bottom and hand pumps at the top attached by a pipe in between.

The following are the considerations for building a safe and sanitary well:

Location Must be at least 15 m away from sources of contamination. Must not be >100 m from households.
Lining Must be made of brick or stones set in cement to a depth of 6 m, so that water enters from bottom and not sides. Height of lining above ground level must be 60 – 90 cm.
Parapet Wall Must be at least 70 – 75 cm (28 inches) from the ground level.
Platform Should stretch at least 1 m around the well in all directions.
Drain It should be a pucca drain to carry spilled water to a public drain beyond the cone of filtration of the well.
Covering There should be a cement concrete covering over the well.
Hand-pump Should be able to withstand rough handling.
Consumer responsibility Consumers must practice basic precautions before handling the well.
Quality The water standards in terms of quality must be conformed to.

questions.text: An outbreak of guinea worm disease was reported among villagers who used step wells for drinking water. In order to arrest the spread of disease, a decision was made to replace step wells with sanitary and safe wells. All of the following measures would be considered during its construction except:

choices.text: Must be located at least 15 metres away from sources of contamination
A partition space for washing clothes and vessels
Lining must be made to a depth of 6 metres or more
Hand-pump must be made to handle rough use

questions.solution:
Washing clothes, vessels, and bathing must be prohibited around wells to avoid contamination of the water.

Step wells are a type of pucca wells which enable people to descend into the well to fetch water. It is obsolete now, as there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water which can pose a health hazard to the community.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease.

The diseases which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply are called water-washed diseases. 

Some examples of water-washed diseases are:

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Trachoma
  • Scabies
  • Typhus

questions.text: A multipurpose worker is spraying herbicides on aquatic plants as part of vector control measures in your area. Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by this approach?
questions.solution:
Filariasis (caused by B.malayi) is transmitted by Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation. It can be controlled by the use of herbicides to destroy aquatic vegetation.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal faeces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses.

ex: Cholera, typhoid, amoebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrhoeal diseases.
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene.

ex: Scabies, trachoma, flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of waterborne diseases (which are also water-washed).
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water.

ex: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis and some other helminths.

 
Water-related diseases transmitted by insect vectors

Caused by vectors that breed in water

ex: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of purification of water cannot be used on a large scale?
questions.solution:
Berkefeld filter is used for the purification of water on a small scale (ex: in households).

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: When river water is stored properly, by how much percent does the bacterial count drop in the first 5-7 days?
questions.solution:
When river water is stored properly, the bacterial count drops by as much as 90% in the first 5 – 7 days.

Purification during the storage of water is a natural process that takes place by physical, chemical and biological phenomena. Components of water purification include storage, filtration and disinfection.

questions.text: What is the other name for slow sand filters?
questions.solution:
Slow sand filters are also called biological filters.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

Layer of algae and diatoms on supernatant water
Layer of alum flocculate on surface of sand bed filter
Layer of algae and diatoms on surface of sand bed filter

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about rapid sand filters?

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity or pressure type

questions.solution:
Frequent washing of the filter bed is required in rapid sand filters. This is done by backwashing.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a ceramic filter that can be used for small scale purification of water?
questions.solution:
Filtration of water on a small scale is done by ceramic filters like Pasteur Chamberland, Berkefeld, and Katadyn filters. 

Ceramic filters are not widely used in India. The most important parts of these filters are the filter candles. Filter candles of the fine type help in removing bacteria but not viruses. These filter candles need to be cleaned periodically as they get clogged with impurities and bacteria.

Types of ceramic filters include:

  • Pasteur Chamberland filter – It has a candle made of porcelain.

Image of a Pasteur Chamberland filter is shown below:

  • Berkefeld filter - it has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr.

Image of a Berkefeld filter is shown below:

  • Katadyn filter - the surface of this filter is coated with a silver catalyst. The incoming bacteria are killed on contact with the surface by the oligodynamic action of silver ions which are liberated into the water.

Image of a Katadyn filter is shown below:

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder
